items.deck: Experts say students should prioritize chances for success in challenging AP classes over padding a transcript.

image.title: 170710_Classroom
image.caption: "Taking a really high AP course load only benefits the student if they can manage their time and achieve a passing grade on the AP exam."

authors.bio: Josh Moody has covered college admissions and international education for U.S. News since 2018. Prior to joining U.S. News he blogged about higher ed trends for Forbes.com and reported on K-12 and higher education, as well as local government, natural disasters and crime for The News & Advance in Lynchburg, Virginia. He began his career as an education reporter for the Kearney Hub in central Nebraska, covering the University of Nebraska—Kearney. Moody is a graduate of the University of Nebraska—Kearney, where he studied journalism and political science.
authors.name: Josh Moody

authors.bio: Josh Moody has covered college admissions and international education for U.S. News since 2018. Prior to joining U.S. News he blogged about higher ed trends for Forbes.com and reported on K-12 and higher education, as well as local government, natural disasters and crime for The News & Advance in Lynchburg, Virginia. He began his career as an education reporter for the Kearney Hub in central Nebraska, covering the University of Nebraska—Kearney. Moody is a graduate of the University of Nebraska—Kearney, where he studied journalism and political science.

items.deck: While at a U.S. high school, international students can sharpen their English and get familiar with American academic culture.

image.title: 170710_ESL
image.alt_text: Focused ESL student in hijab listening to lesson in classroom
image.caption: Many high schools offer English as a Second Language programs to assist nonnative English speakers.

authors.bio:
Anayat Durrani is a Los Angeles-based freelance education reporter for U.S. News, covering international students and global universities. She has been a regular contributor to U.S. News since 2015. Durrani has an M.A. in journalism and international relations from California State University—Sacramento.

In her career as a journalist, she has covered a wide range of topics, such as foreign policy, politics, law, business, technology and more. She served as a U.S.-based political correspondent for years for Cairo’s Al-Ahram Weekly and has been published in numerous international publications. In the U.S., her work has been featured in Military Officer Magazine, PracticeLink Magazine, American Scholar Magazine, EB5Investors.com, several law publications including Plaintiff Magazine, California Lawyer Magazine and more. You can connect with her on LinkedIn.
authors.name: Anayat Durrani

items.deck: Students in the International Baccalaureate diploma program should first weigh their interests.

image.title: 150501_students
image.alt_text: Female student in classroom writing at desk
image.caption: Consider subjects that you enjoy, as well as areas you have not yet studied but would like to explore.

authors.bio: Tiffany Sorensen is a professional tutor and contributing education writer with Varsity Tutors, a live learning platform that connects experts and learners in more than 1,000 subjects, anywhere, at any time. She holds a Bachelor of Arts in Spanish language and literature from Stony Brook University—SUNY and a Master of Science in Spanish-English translation from New York University. While at Stony Brook, she was the recipient of the Teresa Scheuren Award for Excellence in Tutoring. Sorensen is also a certified TEFL teacher and a member of NYU Translators. In addition to U.S. News & World Report, she has been published in FastWeb and Secure Credit Advisors.
authors.name: Tiffany Sorensen

items.deck: As the new school year approaches, two current college students offer time-management and note-taking strategies for success.

image.title: 150928_classroom
image.alt_text: High school students and teacher conducting scientific experiment
image.caption: Class and textbook notes will serve as essential study tools for AP exams.

authors.bio: Caroline Duda is an education writer and Marketing Manager with Varsity Tutors, a live learning platform that connects experts and learners in more than 1,000 subjects, anywhere, at any time. She holds a Master of Fine Arts in creative writing/fiction from the University of Illinois—Urbana-Champaign, a Bachelor of Arts in English from Saint Lawrence University and an Illinois Professional Educator License in secondary (grades 6-12) English education. She has several years of experience as both a teacher and tutor at the elementary, middle, high school and college levels. In addition to U.S. News & World Report, she has been published in Quick & Dirty Tips, ReadWriteThink, SheKnows and TIME.
authors.name: Caroline Duda

Best Colleges 2019 Guidebook

The 2019 edition of the U.S. News Best Colleges guidebook offers comprehensive advice for high school students and their families on researching all the options and choosing the best colleges for them.
